summary.p: Spoke in Ottenbach with a nobleman from Paris, who is supposedly bringing a large pack of hounds as a gift from the Frenchman [Francis I] to the Pope [Paul III] in Rome; however, his interpreter did not contradict the suspicion that the dogs are actually intended for the Turk [Suleiman I]. Greetings. Will send him the book with the letters of Oecolampadius and Zwingli, which he has almost finished reading, if necessary.

div.p: Dear brother, yesterday a nobleman - an acquaintance from Paris - passed through Ottenbach with 5 servants, having approximately 44 very handsome dogs: 36 hunting dogs, one tracking dog, the others truly very large. Among them are two colossi (so to speak) of remarkable size; they have become footsore, so they had to be transported in a basket on a cart. I approached the nobleman, went a fair distance with the dogs, and asked where he was from and where he was going with the gift. He answered me, the Frenchman

is sending the gift to the Pope and did not want to say much more. But I also went with the interpreter for a while, who is a German, and asked him as well. He said the same; after a long time, he asked me how far the sea is beyond Rome; he might not want to go to sea with him. I said to him: "I bet the dogs are meant for the Turk?" He did not say much against it, only that he did not want to help bring them to him; he is indeed concerned. I could not learn more from him, as the nobleman was unwilling to go with me, etc. They consume 2 crowns every day, and he has to pay a lot because they tear things apart, like pigs, dogs, when they become hungry, etc. When he hired the interpreter, he bound him to travel with him on the sea for 8 days; he does not like that.

Nothing more, may God be with you. Greet the relatives for me. If you need the same book, the letters of Oecolampadius and Zwingli, within eight days, I will send it to you; for I have almost finished reading it, and with benefit, for it has given me much light in many places.
Given on the third day before the Feast of Corpus Christi.
To Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his brother in Zurich.
